items.description: River Gowy catchment including areas around Frodsham

floodArea.county: Cheshire East, Cheshire West and Chester, Halton

items.message:
River levels have risen at the Bridge Trafford river gauge as a result of this morning’s rainfall.  We believe there is a possibility of flooding for low lying land and roads around the River Milton and Hornsmill/Hool, Stanney Mill and Thornton Brooks and their tributaries from now until 20:00 today 06/08/23, and river levels are expected to peak to 1.63m around 16:00.

Our incident response staff are closely monitoring weather forecasts and river levels and will issue further flood warnings if necessary.

Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation.

This message will be as the situation changes.

River levels have fallen below levels of concern following yesterday’s 05/08/23 rainfall. However levels will remain high through the day and we are expecting some rain showers this afternoon, which could lead to small rises in river levels again. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: Weather and tide conditions along the coast have improved. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area. The peak spring tides have passed so we are not expecting any further impacts over the next few days. We will continue to monitor the forecast and may re-issue this alert if conditions deteriorate. Continue to be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

This Flood Alert has been removed. 

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 

Coastal conditions should ease for the 06/08/2023 high tide at 23:00 hours.

items.description: Coast from Heacham to north of King's Lynn in Norfolk
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed. 

There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 

Coastal conditions should ease for the 06/08/2023 high tide at 23:00 hours.

items.description: The Essex coast at Coalhouse Fort
items.message: Tide levels are now below the flood risk threshold. The forecast shows no further flood risk from high tides today. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely and issue further Flood Alerts if necessary.

floodArea.county: East Riding of Yorkshire, North Yorkshire
floodArea.riverOrSea: River Derwent, Sea Cut, River Hertford, Burniston Beck

items.message: River levels remain high on the River Derwent due to heavy rainfall over the weekend. Areas most at risk include low lying land, roads and footpaths in the Upper Derwent around Low Marishes. Levels will remain high on Monday. Drier weather is expected later this week and levels should start to fall. We will continue to monitor the forecast. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 21:00 on Monday 07/08/2023, or as the situation changes.

items.message: Tidal water levels are now below the flood risk threshold. The forecast is for no further flood risk from high tides today. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely and issue further Flood Alerts if necessary.

items.description: Middle Level of the Fens in Cambridgeshire and Norfolk
items.message: The risk of flooding has now passed. The forecast is for no further significant rainfall over the next few days, however some heavy showers are still possible. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away.  We will continue to monitor levels closely.
